subject: Re: [junit] using abstract classes to test interfaces
msgSnippet: ... Hmm, we use this basic strategy and it works without problem. I m assuming that there are also proper constuctors in there somewhere (that take a String
messageBody:
--- Dale E Martin <dmartin@...> wrote:
> Hi. I've got a system that is structured as follows. I've got an
> interface "Widget". I've got three implementors of "Widget". I want
> test
> all three implementations, so I write a class, "TestWidget":
>
> public class TestWidget extends TestCase {
...
> }
>
> Now I specialize the construct like so:
> public class TestWidget1 extends TestWidget {
> public Widget1 getWidget(){ return new Widget1(); }
> }

Hmm, we use this basic strategy and it works without problem. I'm
assuming that there are also proper constuctors in there somewhere
(that take a String name argument and have bodies that do super(name)).

I could put together a working example from our code if you like.

Regards,

Rob
